ColumnDataTypes.KitText: #> ColumnDataTypes --print --exampleTitle Get Data Types of All Columns --example Quickly inspect the data types of each column in a dataframe. This is useful to understand the structure of your data and ensuring that numeric, string, and date fields are correctly typed before performing any operations.
ColumnDataTypes.ExampleDescription: Quickly inspect the data types of each column in a dataframe. This is useful to understand the structure of your data and ensuring that numeric, string, and date fields are correctly typed before performing any operations.
ColumnDataTypes.ExampleTitle: Get Data Types of All Columns

ColumnDataTypes.KitText: #> ColumnDataTypes TransactionAmount --print --exampleTitle Get Data Type of a Single Column --example Sometimes we only want to inspect the type of a specific column. This example shows how to print the data type of the TransactionAmount column without examining the entire dataframe.
ColumnDataTypes.ExampleDescription: Sometimes we only want to inspect the type of a specific column. This example shows how to print the data type of the TransactionAmount column without examining the entire dataframe.
ColumnDataTypes.ExampleTitle: Get Data Type of a Single Column

ColumnDataTypes.KitText: #> ColumnDataTypes AccountID LoginAttempts PreviousTransactionDate --print --exampleTitle Get Data Types of Multiple Columns --example Instead of checking all columns, you can target just a few. Here, we retrieve the data types of the AccountID, LoginAttempts, and PreviousTransactionDate columns to verify how these specific fields are stored.
